title: Sri Lanka stocks fall to over 3-wk low; tax hike, high rates weigh
body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka stocks slipped 0.55 percent on Friday (5) to its lowest close in more than three weeks as the government announcement on tax hike coupled with past interest rate increase dented investor sentiment, stockbrokers said.
The All Share Price Index (ASPI) closed 0.55 percent or 44.74 points down at 8,054.77, its lowest close since May 12.
“There is nothing to boost the sentiment. Higher interest rate is the main reason for the market fall,” a stockbroker said.

Sri Lanka Prime Minister Ranil Wickramasinghe implemented a raft of tax hikes for imports while the country is also experiencing record high fuel prices. He also raised the value added tax (VAT) to 12 percent from 8 percent this week.
Though higher taxes are good for state finances and an IMF deal, but they will hit earnings.
The more liquid S&P SL20 index fell 0.9 percent or 24.05 points to 2,647.67.
Foreign investors sold a net 5.2 million rupees’ worth of shares on Friday. The market has witnessed a total foreign outflow of 962 billion rupees so far this year.
The market has so far lost 1.1 percent in June after gaining 6 percent in May. It lost 23 percent in April and 14.5 percent in March.
The market has lost 34.1 percent so far this year after being one of the world’s best stock markets with an 80 percent return last year when large volumes of money were printed.
The daily market turnover was 1.3 billion rupees, around a third of this year’s average daily turnover of 3.9 billion rupees.
Sri Lanka’s sovereign default has already led it to restricted/selective default rating by rating agencies and weighed on investor sentiment.
Investors are also concerned over the steep fall of the rupee from 200 to 370 levels so far in 2022.
All Share Price Index was mainly dragged down by LOLC Holdings, which fell 2.3 percent to 587.75 rupees a share.
Ceylon Tobacco Company fell 3.9 percent to 625 rupees a share.
Expolanka was down 1.5 percent to 210 rupees a share, while John Keells Holdings fell 1.2 percent to 125.25 rupees a share. (Colombo/Jun 03/2022)
